definition: to skimp on the job/to work half-heartedly/not to take the job seriously
to spread/to lay out/to apply (powder, ointment etc)/sufficient (to cover)/enough
to spread out/to develop/to overflow/to amplify/superfluous
Serbia/Serbian/abbr. for 塞爾維亞|塞尔维亚[Sai1 er3 wei2 ya4]
to stop up/to squeeze in/to stuff/cork/stopper
strategic pass/tactical border position
to stop up/to stuff/to cope with
duty/responsibility/to reproach/to blame

sentences.english: I am sorry that he should be so half-hearted about the important work.
sentences.chinese: 遗憾，他对这项重要工作竟这样敷衍塞责。

sentences.english: Don't count on a slacker to help.
sentences.chinese: 不要指望一个敷衍塞责的人来帮你。

definition: to skimp/to work half-heartedly/not to bother
to carry out one's duties perfunctorily/to fulfill one's responsibility
to decline/to avoid/shirking responsibilities/to blame others/to pass the buck/to unload one's responsibilities/to try to get out of a task
to cover up one's faults (idiom)/to whitewash
Formalism (art)
outward devotion but inner opposition (idiom); to pay lip service/to agree overtly, but oppose in secret
to neglect/to trifle with/not to take seriously
to neglect one's duty/dereliction of duty/malpractice
to practice fraud (idiom); by trickery
to go through the motions
to hold accountable/to blame/to censure/to apportion blame
to hold a sinecure (idiom)
satisfied just to get through (idiom); to muddle through/without high ambitions, but getting by
mutually shirking responsibilities (idiom); each blaming the other/passing the buck to and fro/each trying to unload responsibilities onto the other
to become a mere formality
